Abandoned Uranium Mine Claim - An abandoned uranium mine claim is generally associated with a patented or unpatented mining claim or a lease of federal, state, tribal or private lands. A claim may represent a single feature such as a surface or underground excavation, or it may include an area containing a complex of multiple interrelated excavations. As a result, one claim may represent multiple 'mines' listed in other databases. More than 500 abandoned uranium mines claims remain on or near the Navajo Nation with over a thousand of mine features such as open pits, underground workings, audits, rim strips, vertical shafts, and waste piles.

Action Memorandum - EPA’s primary decision document that determines the need for a removal action, authorizes the removal action, identifies the action and cleanup levels (if applicable), and explains the rationale for the removal response.

Abandoned Uranium Mine Region- The abandoned uranium mines are scattered throughout the Navajo Nation. Based on the extent of the cleanup work and locations of the mines sites, EPA refers to the different regions where there are abandoned uranium mines as 'Abandoned Uranium Mine Regions' and divided it up into 6 different areas (Western, Northern, North Central, Central, Southern, and Eastern).

Administrative Order on Consent - A voluntary and enforceable agreement pursuant to the Comprehensive Environmental Response Compensation and Liability Act (known as CERCLA or the Superfund Law), signed by EPA and potentially responsible parties (PRPs), whereby the PRPs agree to perform and/or pay for some or all of the response costs involved in site cleanup.

Consent Decree - Judicial agreement between the federal government and the potentially responsible parties fully or partially settling a claim under CERCLA. The agreement may be for response work, cost recovery, or both.

Engineering Evaluation/Cost Analysis (EE/CA)- An analysis of the cost effectiveness and implementability of cleanup alternatives for cleanup actions at a mine site.

Mine Aliases - Other names that the mine is referred to.

Mine Enforcement Status - Identifying if agreement to assess and cleanup the mine was through an enforcement action with a potentially responsible party or the name of the settlement or consent decree.

Mine Superfund Status - The Superfund milestone completed for the mine. The various milestones are categorized as the following:

  • Preliminary Site Screen Report Completed
  • Removal Site Evaluation Completed/ Removal Site Assessment Completed
  • Engineering Evaluation/Cost Analysis Completed
  • Design for Clean Up Completed
  • Clean Up

Potentially Responsible Party - Any individual or company--including owners, operators, transporters or generators--potentially responsible for, or contributing to a spill or other contamination at a Superfund site. Whenever possible, through administrative and legal actions, EPA requires PRPs to clean up hazardous sites they have contaminated.

Priority Mines - EPA and NNEPA prioritized 46 mines (called priority mines) based on gamma radiation levels, proximity to homes and potential for water contamination identified in preliminary assessments documented in our Site Screen Reports.

Radiation - Energy that travels in the form of waves or high-speed particles. One way that radiation can be released to the environment is during the decay of radioactive elements such as uranium.

Removal Site Evaluation - A report that provides the information needed to determine the extent of contamination at a mine site.

Site Screening Report - Preliminary investigation reports, including scanning of radiation levels at the abandoned uranium mines on Navajo Nation during inspections conducted between 2008-2011. The purpose of the site screen reports was to determine the status and location of identified AUM sites on Navajo Nation.

Superfund - The program operated under the legislative authority of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) and the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA) that funds and carries out EPA's emergency and long-term removal and remedial activities.

Trust Mines - The Navajo Nation negotiated with the United States to address the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission’s role in developing historical uranium mining on Navajo lands. As a result, the United States and the Navajo Nation entered into two legal agreements (the Phase 1 Settlement in 2015 and the Phase 2 Settlement in 2016). These settlements provide funds to assess 16 'priority' mines (Phase 1 Trust Mines) and cleanup as needed, assess an additional 30 mines (Phase 2 RSE Trust Mines), and conduct two water studies located on the Navajo Nation. Visit the Trust Mines website for more information.

Uranium - A heavy, naturally radioactive, metallic element that is used to produce nuclear power and weapons.
